Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial on Ischemic Mitral Regurgitation Management

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomised into two groups

Participants.evidence: Eligibility criteria included patients with moderate IMR and CAD.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised into two groups: CABG alone (n=54) and CABG with mitral valve repair (n=48).

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the efficacy of concomitant mitral valve intervention during coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG).

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was quality of life improvement, measured over four years.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, with allocation concealment ensured.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The CABG with mitral valve repair group showed significant improvement in quality of life and reduced symptoms compared to the CABG alone group.

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were more frequent in the CABG alone group, with 3% experiencing mild complications compared to 1% in the intervention group.
